item.title: Urgent help needed for FNQ marsupial's survival - Sunshine Coast Daily
item.description:
Urgent help needed for FNQ marsupial's survival  Sunshine Coast Daily

NUMBERS of a marsupial known as the rat kangaroo have shrunk so much in the Far North, an “insurance population” is needed to ensure the species does not ...

item.title: 'Drastic reductions' of Australia's northern bettong population reported - The Guardian
item.description:
'Drastic reductions' of Australia's northern bettong population reported  The Guardian

Researchers are calling for urgent measures to save the northern bettong from extinction after a five-year study found just two remaining populations of the animal in the wild. The research, led by WWF Australia working with the Queensland government and scientists from James Cook University, has recommended state and federal governments look to establish insurance populations for the small marsupial known as the “rat kangaroo”. Northern bettongs are endemic to far north Queensland and their numbers have declined dramatically since European colonisation. Studies from the 1980s suggested the...

item.title: ‘It’s Pikachu’: Rare possum goes viral for striking similarity to Pokemon character - RT
item.description:
‘It’s Pikachu’: Rare possum goes viral for striking similarity to Pokemon character  RT

A rare golden possum has found viral fame thanks to its striking similarity with the Pokemon character Pikachu after being saved from almost certain death by a good Samaritan. The orphaned brushtail possum arrived at Boronia Veterinary Clinic in Melbourne in recent weeks after it was found lying on the ground by a member of the public. Vet Stephen Reinisch told The Age that the critter likely fell off her mother’s back. Despite these difficult circumstances, the possum, which is believed to be about five months old, is in good health. READ MORE: 'Only in Australia’: Baby shark’s life is sav...

item.title: A Quest to Save Baby Kangaroos on a Lonely Australian Highway - The New York Times
item.description:
A Quest to Save Baby Kangaroos on a Lonely Australian Highway  The New York Times

Kangaroos can end up as roadkill, but sometimes a joey will live when its mother dies. We check out an orphanage that takes in about 100 baby roos a year.

item.title: Man stumbles on 49,000-year-old aboriginal shelter after getting caught shot in the outback - The Telegraph
item.description:
Man stumbles on 49,000-year-old aboriginal shelter after getting caught shot in the outback  The Telegraph

An ancient rock shelter in outback Australia which shows the Aborigines settled the continent’s interior about 49,000 years ago – far earlier than previously thought - was accidentally discovered by a local elder who stopped his car to go to the toilet in a remote gorge. The room-like shelter, which housed remnants of animal bones, egg shells and stone axes and blades, has been heralded by archaeologists as a ground-breaking discovery which contained some of the clearest evidence that humans lived alongside and hunted megafauna, the giant animals which roamed the planet after the dinosaurs....

item.title: Yellow-footed rock wallabies back from the brink - ABC News
item.description:
Yellow-footed rock wallabies back from the brink  ABC News

Only 20 years ago, the yellow-footed Rock Wallaby was at risk of extinction in South Australia's pastoral country but now a sheep station in the Olary Ranges, has the largest stronghold of rock wallabies in the country. In 2002 there were only 60 rock wallabies left living on Mount Victor-Plumbago Station, 440km north east of Adelaide, but now there are more than 700 spread across the 2,000-square kilometre property operated by the Jumbuck Pastoral Group. Station manager Richard Williams credited the dramatic resurgence of the once-endangered marsupial, to their involvement in Operation Bou...

item.title: Pollen-shifter takes a bow - The Australian
item.description:
Pollen-shifter takes a bow  The Australian

The possum, which weighs as little as 7g, has some big attributes — it has the biggest sperm known to any mammal and the biggest male testes to body weight. But it’s the honey possum’s talent for moving masses of pollen around the flower-dotted scrub that ­intrigues scientists. Stephen Hopper, University of Western Australia’s professor of biodiversity, says the possum has evolved as one of the world’s best non-insect pollinators during 40 million years of evolution in an isolated landscape. “We’re exploring the idea that mammals are moving pollen around much more effectively and over longe...

item.title: Country boy delights in Sydney trip - The Advertiser
item.description:
Country boy delights in Sydney trip  The Advertiser

The Heritage Stakes winner from back in September was rather awkwardly placed last on the fence into the corner but Hugh Bowman was able to angle into the clear at the right time letting down beautifully over the last 250m to finish 0.5-lens second. Nice work. Tuesday’s heats were marked by several very good performances from a number of 2YO’s. Some we know, others yet to race. Chief among them was Peter and Paul Snowden’s flashy Choisir colt ULTRAMARINE who races in the James Harron colours. The colt was a pretty reasonable 3.3-lens second to Star Turn’s very exciting three-quarter-brother...

item.title: Bilby’s nervous step from brink - The Australian
item.description:
Bilby’s nervous step from brink  The Australian

Threatened Species Commissioner Gregory Andrews said ­bilbies in the wild were extremely rare — with no wild populations left in South Australia and few in Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Queensland — which meant growth at Venus Bay, 400km west of Adelaide, was helpful. “The bilby is rarer than Africa’s white rhinoceros; it’s about as rare in the wild as China’s giant panda. That’s why this project is a small part of a much larger program in native areas across Australia,” Mr Andrews said. “This is a small but positive part of a national program to save what is Australia’s mos...

item.title: Red-tailed phascogale given sanctuary lifeline - ABC News
item.description:
Red-tailed phascogale given sanctuary lifeline  ABC News

A feral predator-free zone in Western Australia could become home to the largest population of a mysterious marsupial with an unusually chivalrous mating system. The red-tailed phascogale is a small, carnivorous animal weighing less than a deck of cards and is largely unknown to the public, unlike its famous relative the Tasmanian devil. According to ecologist Laura Ruykys from the Australian Wildlife Conservancy (AWC), that anonymity stems from the creature's shy behaviour. "They're cryptic and small in size and nocturnal," she said. "They are charismatic but they're not as big and charism...

item.title: Fiona the Unemployed Bettong: 'Is this government seriously trying to redefine inequality?' - The Guardian
item.description:
Fiona the Unemployed Bettong: 'Is this government seriously trying to redefine inequality?'  The Guardian

Fiona the Unemployed Bettong: 'Is this government seriously trying to redefine inequality?'

item.title: Aboriginal ancestors ‘were jewellers’ - The Australian
item.description:
Aboriginal ancestors ‘were jewellers’  The Australian

Australian-led researchers have discovered 30,000 year-old wearable art fashioned from animals unique to the scorpion-shaped Indonesian island of Sulawesi, just 1.5km from a rock art gallery recently revealed as one of the world’s oldest. The finds, revealed this morning in the journal PNAS, provide new evidence of sophistication among our region’s supposedly backward earliest inhabitants. They also suggest that the bizarre creatures encountered by modern humans after they crossed the Wallace Line, the deep stretch of water separating Asia and Australasia, helped lay the foundation of Abori...

item.title: KI fossil tracks a gateway to the past - The Advertiser
item.description:
KI fossil tracks a gateway to the past  The Advertiser

Scientists from South Australia have discovered what they are calling one of the most diverse fossil trackways sites, from the late Pleistocine era, ever uncovered. Flinders University lecturer in palaeontology Aaron Camens told the Sunday Mail the trackways are able to tell scientists things they would never know from just skeletal fossils alone. “Australian fossil vertebrate trackways are extremely rare and this project was the first of its kind in Australia,” Dr Camens said. “Footprints are better than bones because they show animals interacting. “With footprints we have records of anima...

item.title: Tasmanian Devils fighting cancer back in the wild - The Telegraph
item.description:
Tasmanian Devils fighting cancer back in the wild  The Telegraph

Tasmanian Devils are being successfully reintroduced to the wild after cancerous facial tumours put the marsupials at risk. Video block text

item.title: Fiona the Unemployed Bettong v. Centrelink's Tudgesquad - The Guardian
item.description:
Fiona the Unemployed Bettong v. Centrelink's Tudgesquad  The Guardian

Fiona the Unemployed Bettong gets Tudged!

item.title: Man Fined $3,000 for Viciously Assaulting Rare Australian Animal - Heat Street
item.description:
Man Fined $3,000 for Viciously Assaulting Rare Australian Animal  Heat Street

By Heat Street Staff | 7:08 am, June 21, 2017 A man has been fined $4,000 Australian dollars ($3,000 USD) for kicking a quokka — a marsupial similar in appearance to a small kangaroo and often described as the world's happiest animal. Harrison McPherson, 20, was filmed by his friend, Corey James, 21, kicking the creature so hard that it crashed into a wall. McPherson's first kick missed the quokka, which is about the size of a domestic cat, but with a second kick he sent it flying as his friend laughed. The incident, which was posted online, took place in February on Rottnest Island off the...

item.title: When Dinosaurs Ruled the Earth, Mammals Took to the Skies - The New York Times
item.description:
When Dinosaurs Ruled the Earth, Mammals Took to the Skies  The New York Times

New fossil discoveries show that prehistoric “squirrels” glided through forests at least 160 million years ago, long before scientists had thought.

item.title: Melbourne jogger thrown around 'like a rag doll' during kangaroo attack - The Telegraph
item.description:
Melbourne jogger thrown around 'like a rag doll' during kangaroo attack  The Telegraph

An Australian jogger has had emergency surgery after being savagely attacked by a rogue kangaroo in suburban Melbourne. Debbie Urquhart, 54, said she feels lucky to be alive after being ripped, kicked and mauled by a two metre tall male kangaroo on Saturday morning while jogging towards a running track in North-East Melbourne. "He came out of nowhere! He was massive and knocked me down," the jogger told radio station 3AW. "He came and hit me like a damn truck." Ms Urquhart told local media that the marsupial repeatedly kicked her on the right side of her body, ripped her clothes and “threw ...

item.title: ‘See some possum poo, pick it up — pretty please’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
‘See some possum poo, pick it up — pretty please’  The Advertiser

The western council is enlisting its residents to keep an eye out for the faeces of the nocturnal marsupials as part of a plan to build home boxes in trees for possums in the suburbs. The plan aims at discouraging possums from moving into the roofs of western homes. However, before the boxes can be built and installed, the council must work out which species live in the region by examining their poo. Charles Sturt chief executive Paul Sutton says the council wants residents to be on the look out for scats and report to the council about where they have seen them. “We will use this informati...

item.title: Cull kangaroos and eat their meat, ecologist urges - ABC News
item.description:
Cull kangaroos and eat their meat, ecologist urges  ABC News

Australians need to embrace kangaroo meat and help bring booming numbers of the big-footed marsupials under control to protect other species, a veteran ecologist has argued. Associate Professor David Paton, from the University of Adelaide, said the community needed to get behind kangaroo culls in certain regions, and consuming roo meat would ensure the carcasses were not wasted. "If we're going to cull these animals we do it humanely, but we also perhaps should think about what we might use the animals that are killed for," he said. "We shouldn't just simply leave them out in paddocks to ro...

item.title: How this possum cost industry $15 million - The Advertiser
item.description:
How this possum cost industry $15 million  The Advertiser

Since the zone laws were put in place, the risk of extinction for Victoria’s emblem, the Leadbeater’s possum, has noticeably reduced but it is also set to create big cuts to local timber industry revenue, according to a report released by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP). The report delivers an estimate of a $14.77 million loss in profit from sawlog harvesting by 2030, meaning possible closures for sawmill sites across Victoria. This was almost the case for Australia’s largest hardwood sawmill, at Heyfield in Victoria’s east, after the company announced it was...

item.title: Don't mistake these cute quendas for giant rats - ABC News
item.description:
Don't mistake these cute quendas for giant rats  ABC News

Perth researchers are using motion sensor cameras in urban backyards to better understand the lives of quendas in the city. Anecdotal evidence suggests quendas, also known as southern brown bandicoots, are regular visitors to gardens around Perth. Scientists at Murdoch University have partnered with the City of Mandurah to search for hard proof. They have recruited residents to a project which places cameras in backyards to learn more about the movement and behaviour of quendas. Dr Catherine Baudains from the university's School of Veterinary and Life Sciences told ABC Radio Perth that peop...

item.title: Wombat cull permit rules 'tightened', as calls grow to halt 'insanity' of legal kills - ABC News
item.description:
Wombat cull permit rules 'tightened', as calls grow to halt 'insanity' of legal kills  ABC News

Tasmanian conservationists are ramping up efforts to stop the government allowing farmers to legally kill up to 50 of Australia's best-known marsupials a year to protect crops. An online petition by a group called Wombat Warriors has amassed more than 3,000 signatures calling on Primary Industries Minister Jeremy Rockliff to cease issuing cull permits while the wombat population continues to be affected by the deadly sarcoptic mange disease, which has depleted populations around Australia. Photo: Wombats pushing under a fence at night. (Supplied: DPIPWE) In February, the ABC reported more t...

item.title: Rare White Koala Born At Australia Zoo - International Business Times
item.description:
Rare White Koala Born At Australia Zoo  International Business Times

Australia Zoo has a new resident: a rare white baby koala. The joey has caused excitement in Oz because she is lighter-colored than her siblings. The new koala, who has yet to be named, was born to parents Tia and Slater in January “and is now venturing out into the world from the safety of her mum’s pouch,” Australia’s tourism website reported. Out of 12 joeys born at the zoo this season, this koala is the only white one. Koalas, which are marsupials not bears, putting them in the same family as kangaroos, opossums, wallabies and Tasmanian devils, generally have fur that ranges between lig...

item.title: Heart of the Nation - The Australian
item.description:
Heart of the Nation  The Australian

Bob the joey has enriched all their lives in unforeseen, wonderful ways in the seven months since then. When Brooke and her fella Andy found him by the roadside that night, still in his dead mother’s pouch – she’d been hit by a car – they had no idea how to care for him, but Brooke’s nurturing instinct kicked in. She fashioned a cosy pouch from a Bob the Builder pillowcase (hence the name) and Googled for a crash course in infant marsupials. Turns out it wasn’t rocket science: regular bottle-feeding with special formula and lots of love. Bob quickly came to see the teen as a surrogate mothe...

item.title: Diners Surprised to Be Joined by Koala in Adelaide Restaurant. Credit - Emily Ioannou-Mena and Xenia Ioannou via Storyful - The Advertiser
item.description:
Diners Surprised to Be Joined by Koala in Adelaide Restaurant. Credit - Emily Ioannou-Mena and Xenia Ioannou via Storyful  The Advertiser

Diners at the Ghengis Khan Mongolian barbecue restaurant in Rostrevor, Adelaide, were surprised to be joined by a curious koala on June 18. Emily Ioannou-Mena followed the marsupial as it made its way from the car park through the dining room. Koala Rescue eventually came and took the animal to safety, local reports said. Credit: Emily Ioannou-Mena and Xenia Ioannou via Storyful

item.title: 'Cane-toad-smart' quolls to be bred in the NT - ABC News
item.description:
'Cane-toad-smart' quolls to be bred in the NT  ABC News

An experimental technique that trains native animals not to eat cane toads is being trialled on an island off the Northern Territory coast. Thirty-five northern quolls have been taken to Indian Island, 41 kilometres west of Darwin to test the theory. Cane toads are partly responsible for the northern quoll being placed on the endangered species list. University of Melbourne PhD candidate Ella Kelly said the quolls hailed from Queensland, the NT, and those bred from parents from the two areas. Photo: The little critters have been fed small pieces of cane toad meat as part of the trial. (ABC ...

item.title: Injured and dead roadside joeys rise as kangaroo numbers surge - ABC News
item.description:
Injured and dead roadside joeys rise as kangaroo numbers surge  ABC News

Wildlife carers are urging caution on roads as seasonal change and urban sprawl leads to an increasing number of joey-carrying kangaroos being killed or injured in collisions. Saving 'pinkies' - If it is safe to do so, gently check the pouch of the dead kangaroo - If there is a joey there gently remove it, wrap it in warm material and take it to the nearest vet or wildlife carer - Do not offer the marsupial food or water - If you are unable to check the pouch take note of the location or mark the injured of dead kangaroo - If you have found injured wildlife in WA call the Wildcare Helpline ...

item.title: 'Cutest quokka ever': Australian marsupial looks joyful as it jumps towards man - The Telegraph
item.description:
'Cutest quokka ever': Australian marsupial looks joyful as it jumps towards man  The Telegraph

A photograph of a small native Australia animal leaping towards a camera has gone viral and been described as “the cutest quokka snap ever”. The image of the quokka – a small tree-climbing wallaby – was taken by Campbell Jones, 21, during a visit to Rottnest Island, off the coast of south-west Australia. Mr Jones said he had been bike riding on the island and stopped to take out his camera when the quokka approached. He said it appeared only to be happy to be the subject of his photographs. Wanted a hug too?! Copyright for this picture is held by @rottnestfastferries , please direct all u...

item.title: Would you like possum with that? - The Australian
item.description:
Would you like possum with that?  The Australian

The nocturnal marsupial could soon be on the menu in South Australia if changes to the state’s food code to expand the definition of game meat are approved. While goat, rabbit, hare, kangaroo and wallaby are hunt-able and legally edible already, South Australians could soon be buying cuts of buffalo, camel, deer, donkey, horse, pig and possum. Tasmanian chef Sharon Cameron, who runs the Bracknell Hotel 30km outside Launceston, said possum was a delicacy for the adventurous. She serves possum-meat chipolatas on a menu that aims to expand her customers’ culinary experiences. “It’s a subtle me...

item.title: Death by 1,000 penalty rate cuts, starring Fiona the Underemployed Bettong - The Guardian
item.description:
Death by 1,000 penalty rate cuts, starring Fiona the Underemployed Bettong  The Guardian

Join a union now! A message from Fiona the Underemployed Bettong

item.title: New hope in superbug fight: Tasmanian devil milk - CNN
item.description:
New hope in superbug fight: Tasmanian devil milk  CNN

Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck's occasional enemy, the voracious Tasmanian devil, may pose a threat to something we'd actually like to see disappear from this planet: the superbug. Researchers in Australia have suspected that Tasmanian devils and other marsupials carry particularly powerful chemicals in their bodies to help their young grow. Marsupials are those mammals that are born incredibly early in their development and grow into the furry creatures you'd recognize only after spending a couple months suckling inside their mothers' pouches; think kangaroos and opossums. Australia is home to ...

item.title: Australia's giant wombat-like marsupial may have been migratory - ABC News
item.description:
Australia's giant wombat-like marsupial may have been migratory  ABC News

The largest marsupial to have ever lived, Australia's giant wombat-like Diprotodon, may have been a migratory species, an analysis of a fossil tooth suggests. Key points: - Diprotodons are giant wombat-like marsupials that lived in Australia between 1.6 million and 45 million years ago. - Scientists analysed a 300,000 year-old incisor tooth from a Diprotodon found on the Darling Downs. - Cyclical changes in chemicals in the tooth suggests the animal made round trips of up to 200 kilometres a year. The Diprotodon optatum was a 3,000-kilogram herbivore that stood 1.8 metres tall at the should...

item.title: Why you should eat kangaroo meat - The Advertiser
item.description:
Why you should eat kangaroo meat  The Advertiser

New government data shows Australia’s kangaroo population is close to hitting 50 million. In 2016, there were almost 45 million kangaroos in Australia, compared to about 27 million in 2010. It’s understood the huge rise in numbers in recent years is mainly due to environmental conditions; high rainfall has resulted in more food. Experts are now encouraging people to hunt the Australian native animal and eat more kangaroo meat. According to a report published by the Victorian Department of Sustainability and Environment, kangaroos are seen as national pests. They damage fences, compete with ...

item.title: This might be the cutest thing you see today - The Advertiser
item.description:
This might be the cutest thing you see today  The Advertiser

Young animal lover Pareesa Amini came face-to-face with a red kangaroo this week at Cleland Wildlife Park. The park is currently full of joeys peeking out of pouches, to the delight of two-year-old Pareesa and her family. Sahil Amini, 40, from Parkholme, said his daughter loved animals, and getting up close to the kangaroos made them “feel like a friend”. “I thought she would get scared but she is very friendly and she loves them,” he said. Mr Amini said Cleland was a great place to take family visiting from overseas. “The main attraction is the kangaroos and the koalas,” he said. Cleland W...

item.title: Pet owners are going native - The Australian
item.description:
Pet owners are going native  The Australian

Gregory Andrews said he had incurred threats from animal rights activists of “rape”, being “blown up by ISIS” or having his family “poisoned with 1080” over his high-profile campaign against feral cats that paradoxically just won him an Invasive Species Council award. Despite those isolated threats (some reported to the Australian Federal Police) and criticism from the likes of French actress Brigitte Bardot and British singer Morrissey, Mr Andrews said the Australian public’s reaction to his campaign had been overwhelmingly positive. He is determined to go one step further by easing the pa...

item.title: Three New Marsupials, All Extinct, Discovered In South America - International Business Times
item.description:
Three New Marsupials, All Extinct, Discovered In South America  International Business Times

Finding fossils of species that are no longer alive gives us an insight to the incredible diversity of nature and life, but it also often raises a pertinent question: why did the species go extinct? And as science progresses, theories are often formed and just as often, discredited. Such a question has cropped up again, with the discovery of three extinct marsupial species (and indications of a fourth) in South America. The fossil find tells us that a little-known marsupial family, the Palaeothentidae, was diverse and widespread across the continent before it disappeared in entirety about 1...

item.title: How exposing bettongs to predators is improving their chances - ABC News
item.description:
How exposing bettongs to predators is improving their chances  ABC News

Tiny marsupials in South Australia's Arid Lands are defying the odds and adapting to live alongside their predators. Burrowing bettongs were once widespread across arid and semi-arid areas in the south, central and western parts of Australia, but now are only usually found on islands or inside fenced reserves where they are safe from feral foxes and cats. But scientists working at the Arid Recovery Reserve near Roxby Downs observed more than 200 of the endangered burrowing bettongs outside the fenced-off reserve last month, despite the existence of a number of feral cats. External Link: Bur...

item.title: Rogue roo makes strange bedfellow - The Advertiser
item.description:
Rogue roo makes strange bedfellow  The Advertiser

The two were reclining at 6.40am when for reasons unknown the marsupial missile smashed through the front window of their Torquay home. “An almighty crash and the next thing we’ve got this kangaroo through the front window of our bedroom,” Mr McConnell said. “It landed on the bed only a matter of a few feet from my wife Norma’s head. It smashed the glass of course so it must have taken a running jump at the window. “I don’t know whether it was frightened by something or whether it saw its reflection in the window but being outside and then jumping through the window seems quite an unusual t...

item.title: Inside the Naracoorte Caves, one of the world's richest fossil sites - ABC News
item.description:
Inside the Naracoorte Caves, one of the world's richest fossil sites  ABC News

In 1857, guided by the flickering light of a candle deep in a cave at Naracoorte in South Australia, the reverend Julian Tenison-Woods stumbled across thousands of tiny bones of rodents and small marsupials buried at the base of crystal columns. Without knowing it, Woods had found a time machine of sorts — a record of biodiversity and environment spanning more than half a million years. Now Naracoorte Caves are known as one of the world's best fossil sites, a place where marsupial lions, enormous kangaroos and giant monitor lizards met their deaths and were preserved by layers of sand. But ...

item.title: Wanted: One Everest spot for Spieth - The Advertiser
item.description:
Wanted: One Everest spot for Spieth  The Advertiser

What more can SPIETH do to earn his place in Australia’s $10m race? Heys could well be asking himself the same question. With any luck, Spieth should already be a dual Group 1 winner and his trial win at Warwick Farm was as good, probably better, than this X-Factor extraordinaire has ever gone at the trials. Spieth won his 800m heat edging out Godolphin three-year-old MARSUPIAL with an eye-catching effort from the fourth placed CONDOR HEROES who was ridden with a sit rather than go out and lead by 10 lengths which he could have easily done. Genuine Caulfield and Melbourne Cup contender INFE...

item.title: National park's black-flanked rock wallabies make a return - ABC News
item.description:
National park's black-flanked rock wallabies make a return  ABC News

For decades it was thought the black-flanked rock wallaby was extinct in the Kalbarri National Park — driven out by feral pests and predators. But the endangered species is staging a comeback so strong authorities say it could become a regular sight in the park's network of remote gorges in WA's Mid West. The animal's resurgence started in 2015, after a pair of the black-flanked rock wallabies and their joey were spotted perched on a rocky outcrop by rock climbers. In May of last year, with funding from the World Wildlife Foundation, 23 wallabies from bigger populations in the Wheatbelt wer...

item.title: Tasmanian Tigers’ Brains Yield Clues Long After Extinction - The New York Times
item.description:
Tasmanian Tigers’ Brains Yield Clues Long After Extinction  The New York Times

The tale of the Tasmanian tiger was tragic. Once numerous across Tasmania, the doglike marsupial was branded a sheep killer by colonists in the 1830s and hunted to extinction. The last of its kind, Benjamin, died in a zoo in 1936, and with it many secrets into the animals’ lives were lost. The striped creature, which is also known as the thylacine, was hardly studied when it was alive, depriving scientists of understanding the behavior of an important predator from Australia’s recent biological past. Now, for the first time, researchers have performed neural scans on the extinct carnivore’s...

item.title: Pygmy possum fighting back - The Advertiser
item.description:
Pygmy possum fighting back  The Advertiser

The mouse-sized mountain pygmy possum’s numbers have swelled to beyond 3000 in the alpine regions of Victoria and NSW. A review into the Federal Government’s threatened species strategy, to be released today, shows a plan to kill more than 2 million feral cats has sparked the revival of a handful of rare native animals. The tiny possum, Australia’s only hibernating marsupial, was thought for decades to be extinct before one was found at a ski resort at Mount Hotham in 1966. Surveys in Kosciuszko National Park found its numbers increased by more than 20 per cent. Threatened Species Commissio...

item.title: Secret cabinet documents show wombats, quolls and more Aussie animals at risk - ABC News
item.description:
Secret cabinet documents show wombats, quolls and more Aussie animals at risk  ABC News

Many of Australia's most iconic marsupials will lose protection from logging bulldozers, under a radical overhaul proposed in secret Forestry Corporation documents. The documents, obtained by the ABC, propose the elimination of long-standing threatened species protections, such as site-survey rules, in many NSW state forests. Intense clearing in northern regions, and increased access to protected stream-banks across the state are other major changes. Environmentalists say if current rules are trashed, protected marsupials including koalas, wombats, quolls, and gliders will be stealthily eli...

item.title: Have you seen this quokka? - The Australian
item.description:
Have you seen this quokka?  The Australian

“Steve” is from a rare, thriving quokka colony on the holiday destination of Rottnest Island, some 22km from Perth. The friendly marsupials are widely adored. Steve is thought to have come to the mainland on a rubbish ship on January 4. The alarm was raised after a Canning Vale depot worker took a photo of the “very big rat”. His colleague recognised Steve’s true identity and contacted the Rottnest Island Authority. According to the WA Police Facebook page, the authority is offering a reward: a day trip to the island for whoever finds the escapee.

item.title: Doggie duo help study of Brisbane koalas - The Advertiser
item.description:
Doggie duo help study of Brisbane koalas  The Advertiser

Strapped into their workwear harnesses, the dogs are entrusted by the Brisbane City Council to track down koala scats to better understand the vulnerable marsupial's behaviour. It's hoped the hardy hounds will help collect enough material to inform research on genetic diversity, movements and health. "Understanding more about Brisbane's koala population is important to help protect the species," lord mayor Graham Quirk said. "In Brisbane, and many other parts of Australia, their numbers have dropped rapidly due to habitat loss, dog attacks, vehicle strikes and disease." The genetic survey h...

item.title: Research shows WA's northern quolls are avoiding feral cat baits - ABC News
item.description:
Research shows WA's northern quolls are avoiding feral cat baits  ABC News

Northern quolls in Western Australia's Pilbara region may be learning to avoid toxic baits aimed at decimating feral cat numbers, according to researchers. The small carnivorous marsupials were once abundant in northern Australia, but introduced species such as the cane toad and the feral cat have wreaked havoc on their populations. PhD candidate at Charles Darwin University Billy Ross has been monitoring the feral cat and quoll populations at pastoral stations near the mining town of Pannawonica. He said the endangered species falls right within the size range for feral cat prey. "Feral ca...

item.title: Tasmanian devil’s milk could be key to combating drug-resistant superbugs – study - RT
item.description:
Tasmanian devil’s milk could be key to combating drug-resistant superbugs – study  RT

Superbugs have proven to be too stubborn for antibiotics, but it appears a much simpler solution could be available. Scientists have found that milk from Tasmanian devils have the power to kill drug-resistant bacteria. Scientists at the University of Sydney turned to the marsupials because of their biology – particularly because the underdeveloped young have an immature immune system when they are born, yet survive in their mother's pouch by suckling milk for about four months. This led the researchers to believe the milk made by Tasmanian devils was full of beneficial qualities which help ...

item.title: Concerns for viral 'Bunnings possum' caught snacking on saplings - ABC News
item.description:
Concerns for viral 'Bunnings possum' caught snacking on saplings  ABC News

A common brushtail possum caught on camera feasting on a smorgasbord of offerings in a Brisbane Bunnings nursery department is most likely just looking for a source of water, an expert says. The 'Bunnings possum' has gone viral, with the original video of the brazen marsupial munching on some lettuce plants being viewed more than 634,700 times since being posted on the ABC Brisbane Facebook page on Friday. Another video posted on Sunday of the same possum eating from a strawberry plant is also gaining tracking with more than 260,000 views and more than 5,500 shares. However some commenters ...

item.title: Possum breaks into Bunnings for a snack - The Advertiser
item.description:
Possum breaks into Bunnings for a snack  The Advertiser

Passing up one of the store’s famous sausage sandwiches, the little marsupial went straight for the nursery section. The brushtail possum was caught on camera red handed by Yvonne McRostie at the Carseldine store, tucking into some of the potted lettuce seedlings that were on display. “I couldn’t believe it happened in the middle of the day, I’ve never seen a possum in the middle of the day,” Ms McRostie told ABC. She said staff member eventually came and shooed the cheeky animal away. “It looks like it was a regular occurrence there, it went into the wall of pots and went up there.” Accord...

item.title: Teeth of rhinoceros-sized wombat found at swamp north of Melbourne - ABC News
item.description:
Teeth of rhinoceros-sized wombat found at swamp north of Melbourne  ABC News

Archaeologists have uncovered teeth from the extinct Diprotodon, a giant wombat-like marsupial, at a swamp north of Melbourne. Key points: - Dig at Lancefield Swamp uncovers teeth and bones from extinct megafauna - Aboriginal artefacts also found at the site - Archaeologists and palaeontologists hoping to shed new light on what happened at the site A team of archaeologists and palaeontologists from Victorian universities, traditional owners and Museum Victoria set up the dig at Lancefield Swamp this week. Dr Jillian Garvey said the Diprotodon, the largest known marsupial species, weighed ab...

item.title: Two men in custody over quokka attack caught on video - ABC News
item.description:
Two men in custody over quokka attack caught on video  ABC News

Two men are being interviewed after footage emerged of a man violently kicking a quokka, one of Western Australia's most loved and iconic marsupials, on Rottnest Island. The footage appears to show a young man chasing a quokka around the front yard of accommodation on the holiday island. He aims a kick at the animal and misses, chases it around a tree and then kicks again, this time connecting. The quokka is sent flying into a wall. The quokka is still moving after the impact with the wall, and it is shown desperately trying to flee as the man continues to give chase. A man can be heard lau...

item.title: Culling foreign predators allows rare possum sighting in WA National Park - ABC News
item.description:
Culling foreign predators allows rare possum sighting in WA National Park  ABC News

The telltale sound of a brushtail possum on the roof may be annoying for some, but the discovery of the species in WA's north is a sign that the eradication of foreign predators has been successful. Photo: Kalbarri National Park is home to many native species, including the black-flanked rock wallaby. (ABC Midwest and Wheatbelt: Laura Meachim) A brushtail possum was pictured in Kalbarri National Park, 485km north of Perth, in the first documented sighting of the species in northern WA. It was caught on a remote sensing camera, used to monitor black-flanked rock wallabies that were reintrodu...

item.title: 'No one will believe me': Albino quoll believed to be a world first discovered in WA - ABC News
item.description:
'No one will believe me': Albino quoll believed to be a world first discovered in WA  ABC News

With snow white fur and distinct red eyes, researchers have discovered what is thought to be the first ever albino quoll near Port Hedland, in Western Australia's Pilbara region. Quolls are normally light brown and spotted, but this female has bright, white fur and distinct red eyes. Dr Judy Dunlop, a researcher at the Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attractions, said she got a shock when she made the discovery. "As far as I can tell it's the first albino of any quoll species, so it's a very exciting discovery," she said. "I was actually on my own when I saw this thing and I wa...

item.title: Chargrilled kangaroo restores balance to an overrun outback - Financial Times
item.description:
Chargrilled kangaroo restores balance to an overrun outback  Financial Times

One of the first things you notice when moving to Australia is that most native animals can kill you. There are the fearsome saltwater crocodiles, poisonous snakes, sharks, blue-ringed octopi and even a species of spider that can crawl out from under the toilet seat to give you a nasty bite. But no one told me about the dangers posed by the kangaroo, a supposedly cute marsupial and national emblem that is wreaking havoc on the nation’s roads and posing a threat to food supplies. The problem is that there are too darn many of the critters, they have poor roadside etiquette and a notoriously ...

item.title: Kangaroo attacks couple in northeastern Australia, injures woman - Reuters
item.description:
Kangaroo attacks couple in northeastern Australia, injures woman  Reuters

Australian wildlife carers Jim and Linda Smith are lucky to be alive, an ambulance official said, after they were attacked by a kangaroo in northeastern Queensland state. The Smiths were feeding wild kangaroos on their property in the Darling Downs when a grey kangaroo buck struck out at Jim Smith, knocking him to the ground. The kangaroo attacked his wife, Linda, when she ran to help him, leaving her with a collapsed lung, broken ribs, cuts and scratches. "It's scary, it knocked me over once or twice and once they grab you, you can see what they do", Jim said, showing his injuries. It was ...

item.title: Funnel-web spider venom found to contain potent killer of skin cancer cells - New Atlas
item.description:
Funnel-web spider venom found to contain potent killer of skin cancer cells  New Atlas

Discoveries of potentially life-saving peptides in the venom of deadly animals are, counter-intuitively, not all that rare. Scorpions, rattlesnakes and funnel-web spiders have all provided scientists with promising building blocks for next-generation medicines, and a dangerous Australian arachnid has again reared its head with a compound in its venom found to be a potent killer of melanoma cells. The research was carried out by scientists at Australian research institute QIMR Berghofer and the University of Queensland, who were inspired by a peptide found in the Brazilian spider Acanthoscur...

item.title: A tree kangaroo thought extinct was photographed for the first time ever - Quartz
item.description:
A tree kangaroo thought extinct was photographed for the first time ever  Quartz

In 1928, Ernst Mayr, then one of the world’s most respected evolutionary biologists, spotted a species of tree kangaroo he hadn’t seen before high in the mountains in what is now West Papua, Indonesia. He shot it and sent the pelt to the Natural History Museum in London. That was the first, and last, recorded contact between the Wondiwoi tree kangaroo and Western science. “It is one of the most poorly known mammals in the world,” Mark Eldridge, a marsupial biologist at the Australian Museum in Sydney, told National Geographic. In July, Michael Smith, an amateur biologist from the UK, trekke...

item.title: Baby possums under attack from pets - The Advertiser
item.description:
Baby possums under attack from pets  The Advertiser

The Minton Farm Native Animal Rescue Centre, at Cherry Gardens, has taken in 15 tiny ringtail possums, weighing between 45g and 120g, over the past two weeks after they were mauled by cats and a dog. “There’s so many (baby possums) out and about and people let their cats out more because the weather is nice,” the centre’s owner Bev Langley said. Sadly, the first possum to arrive at the centre was too badly injured and died last week. “(It) had puncture holes through its chest and thigh where the tooth had punctured into the actual muscle,” Ms Langley said. Others suffered what appeared to b...

item.title: Native life thriving on cane toad-infested island - ABC News
item.description:
Native life thriving on cane toad-infested island  ABC News

How do cane toads survive on a remote island in Western Australia's far north that has no permanent water source? It is a question puzzling researchers, who have been monitoring how toad populations interact with native wildlife on Adolphus Island, 35km north of Wyndham in the Cambridge Gulf. The Parks and Wildlife Department and local Indigenous rangers first discovered cane toads on the island after a flood event in 2014. Using remote cameras, staff from WA's cane toad strategy have since observed an array of native species calling the island home over the years, including the yellow spot...

item.title: Cats don't just kill with their claws; 'toxo' hitting native wildlife hard - ABC News
item.description:
Cats don't just kill with their claws; 'toxo' hitting native wildlife hard  ABC News

By Leon Compton At the Trowunna Wildlife Park, Liv Tack cuts into the brain of the animal splayed in front of her. The eastern barred bandicoot on the necropsy table died yesterday. "Ah," she said, after pointing with her scalpel. "The brain is soft and mushy." She has placed samples of the male bandicoot's brain, kidney, lung and liver into a specimen jar, to be sent to the Department of Primary Industry labs for testing. The third year veterinary science student has made her assessment based on the haemorrhaging she has found on the lungs and the condition of the brain. "I would say with ...

item.title: Residents fight move to cull rare mob of up to 1,000 'suburban' kangaroos - ABC News
item.description:
Residents fight move to cull rare mob of up to 1,000 'suburban' kangaroos  ABC News

By Rebecca Trigger There are calls to save up to 1,000 kangaroos living in a suburban nature reserve in Perth's south from a cull, after a report found the population was damaging the vegetation and had reached "unsustainable" levels. The Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attractions (DBCA) is considering a cull at Thomsons Lake Reserve but some residents want the kangaroos preserved, while the local council has flagged concerns a cull could cause an outbreak of Ross River virus in the area. The reserve, less than a 30-minute drive from Perth's city centre, is home to an abundanc...

item.title: Hope for Australia’s northern quoll – and other animals with a taste for poison - The Guardian
item.description:
Hope for Australia’s northern quoll – and other animals with a taste for poison  The Guardian

Australia’s northern quoll, one of the world’s rarest carnivores, has developed a feeding habit that puts its very existence in peril. The squirrel-sized marsupial turns out to have a fondness for the poisonous flesh of invasive cane toads, introduced into Australia in the 1930s. And this appetite has wiped out vast numbers of the species across the country. As a result, the northern quoll is now considered to be nationally endangered. But scientists have launched a remarkable project aimed at saving the little nocturnal hunters. They have pinpointed an isolated group of quolls that have ev...

item.title: Logging that kills gliders done so intensively 'it may have breached law' - ABC News
item.description:
Logging that kills gliders done so intensively 'it may have breached law'  ABC News

A logging company owned by the Victorian Government may have broken the law during the controversial clearing of forest that's home to a threatened species, according to a formal complaint. Key points: - Conservationists allege logging in one East Gippsland experimental area was done so intensively, it may have breached the law - Official complaint lodged with Environment Department - VicForests denies it breached any laws with its clearing On Sunday, the ABC revealed VicForests was conducting an experiment in which it logs the habitat of the threatened greater glider using different techni...

item.title: Australia’s Endangered Quolls Get Genetic Boost From Scientists - The New York Times
item.description:
Australia’s Endangered Quolls Get Genetic Boost From Scientists  The New York Times

“What we’re doing is nothing unnatural,” said the author of a study to produce quolls that don’t like the taste of deadly toads. “It’s just matchmaking.”

item.title: Mobs of kangaroos take to streets of Australia's capital over food shortages - CNN
item.description:
Mobs of kangaroos take to streets of Australia's capital over food shortages  CNN

Mobs of kangaroos have been raiding patches of grass in the Australian capital Canberra, driven to the city's sports fields, back yards and roadsides by food scarcity. Canberra residents have taken to social media with images of the jumping marsupials exploring outside their usual habitats. But beyond the cute photo opportunities, the hungry kangaroos are at risk of dying on the roads as their feeding times coincide with rush hour. Canberra has more than 30 nature reserves, with most hosting hundreds of Eastern Grey Kangaroos, and it is not unusual to see them in the reserves or in roads or...

item.title: Loss of habitat blamed for kangaroo breaking into home and causing havoc - The Independent
item.description:
Loss of habitat blamed for kangaroo breaking into home and causing havoc  The Independent

A kangaroo broke into a family home and left it looking "like a scene from the movie Psycho", according to a wildlife rescuer who took in the creature. Manfred Zabinskas who has named the marsupial "Norman Bates" after the famous character from Alfred Hitchcock's classic film, said habitat loss could be among the factors behind its behaviour. After entering the home in Melbourne, Australia, the creature smashed windows and destroyed things in the property. Read more - Grass poisoning blamed for condition making kangaroos appear 'drunk' - Australian football match stopped for the most Austra...

item.title: Threatened gliders are 'gonna die' in VicForests' logging experiment, expert says - ABC News
item.description:
Threatened gliders are 'gonna die' in VicForests' logging experiment, expert says  ABC News

A government-owned logging company is conducting a controversial experiment expected to kill native animals that are already heading toward extinction, the ABC can reveal. VicForests is owned by the Victorian Government and logs native forests for profit under exemptions to federal environment law. It is now logging parts of East Gippsland forest at different intensities to measure survival rates of the threatened greater gliders that call it home. VicForests argued the research would assist the conservation of the species, but acknowledged it was likely to kill some of them. In an email se...

item.title: Feral cats filmed preying on nesting Leadbeater's possums - ABC News
item.description:
Feral cats filmed preying on nesting Leadbeater's possums  ABC News

By environment reporter Nick Kilvert Researchers have warned they may have underestimated the threat feral cats pose to the critically endangered Leadbeater's possum, after inadvertently capturing footage of a cat preying on possums as they attempt to leave a nesting box. Ecologists from the University of Melbourne had motion-detecting cameras focussed on artificial nesting boxes as part of a study into nest-box microclimates in the Victorian Central Highlands. But when researcher Leo McComb and his supervisor Dr Natalie Briscoe viewed the footage, they found a feral cat had visited the box...
